text.p: These are some of the leading stories in Kuwait's press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Kuwait's proposed 1997/98 (July-June) budget shows a 1.139 billion dinar ($3.67 billion) shortfall compared to 1.21 billion dinars in the current fiscal year.

- Kuwait pays its $33.4 million share in the $50 million United Nations Iraq-Kuwait Observation (UNIKOM) budget for the year ending in April, U.N. report says. UNIKOM, established after the 1991 Gulf War that ended Iraq's seven-month occupation of Kuwait, is in charge of observing a demilitarised zone straddling the border between the two countries.
- Parliament to publish its own weekly newspaper.

- Crown Prince and Prime Minister Sheikh Saad al-Abdulla al-Sabah is expected to return to Kuwait in the second half of April. Sheikh Saad is in Britain where he received medical treatment following colon surgery in Kuwait in March.
- Kuwait and Syria to sign an agreement to avoid double taxation on investments.
- Sheikh Saad on Tuesday received Minister of State for Cabinet Affairs Abdul-Aziz al-Dakhil in his London residence.
